intro: Dysphania cristata, commonly known as the crowned chenopod, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the Americas. It is a member of the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its distinctive, branched inflorescence that resembles a crown. The plant typically grows as an annual herb with succulent stems and leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its small, inconspicuous flowers are usually green or white, and it produces small, dry fruits called utricles. Dysphania cristata is adapted to thrive in harsh environments, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
